problem: A ball is dropped straight down from a height of 16 feet. If it bounces back each time to a height one-half the height from which it last fell, how far will the ball have traveled when it hits the floor for the sixth time, in feet?
solution: The ball first drops 16 feet. It then travels up 8 feet and down 8 feet. When it hits the floor for the sixth time, it will have traveled $16 + 8 + 8 + 4 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 1/2 + 1/2 = \boxed{47}$ feet.
model_solution:
## Step 1: Calculate the distance the ball travels on the first drop.
The ball is dropped from a height of 16 feet, so it will travel 16 feet downwards.

## Step 2: Calculate the distance the ball bounces back up after the first drop.
The ball bounces back up to a height of one-half the height from which it last fell, so it will bounce back up 16 / 2 = 8 feet.

## Step 3: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the second bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 8 feet it bounced back up to, so it will travel 8 feet downwards.

## Step 4: Calculate the distance the ball bounces back up after the second fall.
The ball bounces back up to a height of one-half the height from which it last fell, so it will bounce back up 8 / 2 = 4 feet.

## Step 5: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the third bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 4 feet it bounced back up to, so it will travel 4 feet downwards.

## Step 6: Calculate the distance the ball bounces back up after the third fall.
## Step 7: The ball will bounce back up to a height of one-half the height from which it last fell, so it will bounce back up 4 / 2 = 2 feet.
## Step 8: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the fourth bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 2 feet it bounced back up to, so it will travel 2 feet downwards.
## Step 9: Calculate the distance the ball bounces back up after the fourth fall.
The ball will bounce back up to a height of one-half the height from which it last fell, so it will bounce back up 2 / 2 = 1 foot.
## Step 10: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the fifth bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 1 foot it bounced back up to, so it will travel 1 foot downwards.
The ball will bounce back up to a height of one-half the height from which it last fell, so it will bounce back up 1 / 2 = 0.5 feet.
## Step 11: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the sixth bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 0.5 feet it bounced back up to, so it will travel 0.5 feet downwards.
## Step 12: Calculate the total distance traveled by the ball when it hits the floor for the sixth time.
Sum up the distances traveled in each step: 16 + 8 + 8 + 4 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 0.5 + 0.5 + 0.25 + 0.25 + 0.125 + 0.125 + 0.0625 + 0.0625 = 46.0625
## Step 13: Sum up the distances traveled in each step: 16 + 8 + 8 + 4 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 0.5 + 0.5 + 0.25 + 0.25 + 0.125 + 0.125 + 0.0625 + 0.0625 + 0.03125 + 0.03125 = 46.0625
## Step 14: 16 + 8 + 8 + 4 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 0.5 + 0.5 + 0.25 + 0.25 + 0.125 + 0.125 + 0.0625 + 0.0625 + 0.03125 + 0.03125

The ball will fall from the height of 2 feet it bounced back up to, so it will travel 2 feet downwards.

## Step 9: Calculate the distance the ball bounces back up after the fourth fall.
The ball will bounce back up to a height of one-half the height from which it last fell, so it will bounce back up 2 / 2 = 1 foot.

## Step 10: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the fifth bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 1 foot it bounced back up to, so it will travel 1 foot downwards.

## Step 11: Calculate the distance the ball falls on the sixth bounce.
The ball will fall from the height of 0.5 feet it bounced back up to, so it will travel 0.5 feet downwards.

## Step 12: Calculate the total distance traveled by the ball when it hits the floor for the sixth time.
Sum up the distances traveled in each step: 16 + 8 + 8 + 4 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 0.5 + 0.5 + 0.25 + 0.25 + 0.125 + 0.125 + 0.0625 + 0.0625 = 46.0625
